title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on 2 Chronicles chapter 21 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of 2 Chronicles Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who reigned in place of Jehoshaphat after he died?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram
questions.explanation: Jehoram, the son of Jehoshaphat, reigned in his stead as stated in 2 Chronicles 21:1.

questions.question: How many brothers of Jehoram are named in 2 Chronicles 21?
questions.explanation: The text lists six brothers: Azariah, Jehiel, Zechariah, Azariah, Michael, and Shephatiah in 2 Chronicles 21:2.

questions.question: What did Jehoshaphat give to his sons besides the kingdom to Jehoram?
options: Silver, gold, precious things, and fenced cities
questions.correctAnswer: Silver, gold, precious things, and fenced cities
questions.explanation: Jehoshaphat gave great gifts of silver, gold, precious things, and fenced cities in Judah to his sons, as per 2 Chronicles 21:3.

questions.question: What did Jehoram do to his brothers when he became king?
questions.correctAnswer: Slew them with the sword
questions.explanation: Jehoram strengthened himself and killed all his brothers with the sword according to 2 Chronicles 21:4.

questions.question: At what age did Jehoram begin to reign?
questions.correctAnswer: 32 years old
questions.explanation: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he began to reign as stated in 2 Chronicles 21:5.

questions.question: Whose daughter did Jehoram marry?
questions.correctAnswer: The daughter of Ahab
questions.explanation: Jehoram had the daughter of Ahab as his wife, as described in 2 Chronicles 21:6.

questions.question: Why did the LORD not destroy the house of David during Jehoram's reign?
options: Because of the covenant with David
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the covenant with David
questions.explanation: God preserved the house of David due to His covenant and promise to David and his descendants forever, as stated in 2 Chronicles 21:7.

questions.question: Which two groups revolted from Judah during Jehoram’s reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Edomites and Libnah
questions.explanation: The Edomites and Libnah revolted from Judah during Jehoram’s reign, as mentioned in 2 Chronicles 21:8 and 2 Chronicles 21:10.

questions.question: What did Jehoram do to the high places in Judah?
options: Made high places and caused fornication
Turned them into altars to the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Made high places and caused fornication
questions.explanation: Jehoram made high places in the mountains of Judah and caused the inhabitants to commit fornication, according to 2 Chronicles 21:11.

questions.question: Who sent a letter to Jehoram warning him of judgment?
questions.correctAnswer: Elijah the prophet
questions.explanation: Elijah the prophet sent a writing to Jehoram warning him of God's judgment, as stated in 2 Chronicles 21:12.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoram walked in the ways of Asa king of Judah.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehoram did not walk in the ways of Asa, but followed the ways of the kings of Israel, as explained in 2 Chronicles 21:12.

questions.question: True or False: The LORD promised to give a light forever to David and his sons.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The LORD promised to give a light to David and his sons forever according to His covenant (2 Chronicles 21:7).

questions.question: True or False: Jehoram was buried with the same honor as his fathers.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehoram was buried in the city of David but not in the sepulchres of the kings, and his people made no burning for him like for his fathers (2 Chronicles 21:19-20).

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'Behold, with a great ______ will the LORD smite thy people, and thy children, and thy wives, and all thy goods:'
questions.correctAnswer: plague
questions.explanation: The LORD said He would smite Jehoram's people with a great plague as written in 2 Chronicles 21:14.

questions.question: Complete this verse: 'And thou shalt have great sickness by disease of thy ______, until thy bowels fall out by reason of the sickness day by day.'
questions.correctAnswer: bowels
questions.explanation: Jehoram was told he would have a disease of his bowels until they fell out due to sickness (2 Chronicles 21:15).

medium.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is struggling with bitterness and unforgiveness toward family members. Based on Jehoram's actions in 2 Chronicles 21, what biblical truth would you share about forgiveness and family?
options: Unforgiveness can lead to destructive actions and spiritual downfall
Family conflicts are normal and should be ignored
Seeking revenge is a way to honor God
questions.correctAnswer: Unforgiveness can lead to destructive actions and spiritual downfall
questions.explanation: Jehoram strengthened himself and slew all his brethren (2 Chronicles 21:4), which led to God's judgment on him (21:12-15). This teaches us the importance of forgiveness and peace within family relationships.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 21 teach us about the consequences of walking contrary to the ways of godly parents in faith?
options: Walking away from godly ways leads to judgment and suffering
It has no effect on one's life
God blesses rebellion if it feels right
questions.correctAnswer: Walking away from godly ways leads to judgment and suffering
questions.explanation: Jehoram did not walk in the ways of Jehoshaphat or Asa (21:12), but followed evil patterns, resulting in plagues and disease as judgment (21:14-15, 21:18). This warns against forsaking godly heritage.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to compromise their faith for political gain. Based on Jehoram’s example, what warning does 2 Chronicles 21 give?
options: Compromise leads to loss of God’s favor and eventual downfall
It is wise to compromise for peace
God rewards political alliances regardless of faith
Faith can be separated from leadership
questions.correctAnswer: Compromise leads to loss of God’s favor and eventual downfall
questions.explanation: Jehoram walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, married Ahab’s daughter, and committed evil (21:6). God’s judgment followed, showing the danger of compromising faith for gain (21:14-15, 21:18).

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 21 instruct believers about trusting God during times of national or personal crisis?
options: Forsaking God leads to rebellion and loss of protection
questions.correctAnswer: Forsaking God leads to rebellion and loss of protection
questions.explanation: Edom and Libnah revolted because Jehoram forsook the LORD (21:8, 21:10). This shows that trust and obedience to God bring security, while forsaking Him results in hardship.

questions.question: A Christian is struggling with temptation to adopt ungodly practices in their community. What biblical principle from 2 Chronicles 21 can guide them?
options: Avoid causing others to stumble by personal compromise
It is acceptable to follow popular customs
God does not mind cultural blending
Personal sins do not affect the community
questions.correctAnswer: Avoid causing others to stumble by personal compromise
questions.explanation: Jehoram caused Jerusalem to commit fornication by building high places and compelling others (21:11). This warns believers against leading others into sin by their own disobedience.

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 21 reveal about God's covenant faithfulness despite human failure?
options: God did not destroy David’s house because of His covenant
God abandons His people immediately when they sin
Covenants are conditional on perfect obedience
God favors only the righteous descendants
questions.correctAnswer: God did not destroy David’s house because of His covenant
questions.explanation: Although Jehoram was evil, the LORD did not destroy David’s house because of the covenant and promise to give a light to David and his sons forever (21:7).

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 21 emphasize the importance of integrity and obedience in leadership?
options: Leaders who disobey God bring ruin upon themselves and their people
Obedience is not necessary if you have power
questions.correctAnswer: Leaders who disobey God bring ruin upon themselves and their people
questions.explanation: Jehoram’s disobedience led to revolts, plagues, and personal suffering (21:8-10, 21:14-15, 21:18). This teaches that integrity and obedience are vital for godly leadership.

questions.question: True or False: According to 2 Chronicles 21, Jehoram was buried with the kings in the sepulchres of the city of David.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehoram was buried in the city of David, but not in the sepulchres of the kings (21:20), indicating a dishonorable burial due to his evil reign.

questions.question: True or False: Jehoram’s sickness was a direct result of God’s judgment for his sins according to 2 Chronicles 21.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: The LORD smote Jehoram with an incurable disease in his bowels as judgment for his sins (21:15, 21:18), demonstrating God’s discipline for disobedience.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 21 teach us about the dangers of marrying ungodly partners?
options: Marrying into ungodly families can lead to following evil ways
It is wise to marry for political alliances
God accepts all marriages regardless of faith
questions.correctAnswer: Marrying into ungodly families can lead to following evil ways
questions.explanation: Jehoram married the daughter of Ahab and followed the evil ways of Israel’s kings (21:6), showing how ungodly marriages can influence spiritual decline.

questions.question: A believer is discouraged by trials and sickness. Based on 2 Chronicles 21, what biblical truth concerning perseverance and judgment would you share?
options: Suffering can be a consequence of sin but God’s covenant remains
Trials are always punishment without hope
Sickness is unrelated to spiritual condition
questions.correctAnswer: Suffering can be a consequence of sin but God’s covenant remains
questions.explanation: Jehoram’s sickness was a judgment for sin (21:14-15, 21:18), yet God’s covenant with David remained (21:7), reminding us that God’s promises endure despite discipline.

questions.question: What is the practical lesson from Jehoram’s violent acts against his brothers in 2 Chronicles 21?
options: Violence and ambition destroy family and invite God’s judgment
Family conflicts should be resolved by force
questions.correctAnswer: Violence and ambition destroy family and invite God’s judgment
questions.explanation: Jehoram killed his brothers to secure his throne (21:4), which was condemned by God and led to his downfall (21:12-15). This warns against ambition that harms family.

questions.question: A church leader is tempted to neglect prayer and obedience. Based on 2 Chronicles 21, what would you advise about spiritual discipline?
options: Neglecting God leads to spiritual and communal decline
Prayer is optional if you lead well
Discipline is not necessary for leaders
questions.correctAnswer: Neglecting God leads to spiritual and communal decline
questions.explanation: Jehoram forsook the LORD (21:10), which led to revolts and judgment (21:8-10). This shows that spiritual discipline is vital for sustaining God’s blessing.

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 21 illustrate the importance of humility and repentance in leadership?
options: Refusing to repent can bring severe consequences
Repentance is not necessary if you have power
questions.correctAnswer: Refusing to repent can bring severe consequences
questions.explanation: Jehoram did not repent but persisted in evil, resulting in God’s severe judgment (21:12-15, 21:18). Humility and repentance are crucial for leaders to maintain God’s favor.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Jehoram was thirty and two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned in Jerusalem ______ years.
questions.correctAnswer: eight
questions.explanation: Jehoram began to reign at age 32 and reigned eight years in Jerusalem (21:5, 21:20). This fact highlights the brevity of his troubled reign.

hard.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from 2 Chronicles Chapter 21.

questions.question: Who succeeded Jehoshaphat as king according to 2 Chronicles 21?
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram
questions.explanation: Jehoram, the son of Jehoshaphat, reigned in his stead as stated in 2 Chronicles 21:1.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 21:4, what drastic action did Jehoram take upon ascending the throne?
options: Slew all his brethren with the sword
questions.correctAnswer: Slew all his brethren with the sword
questions.explanation: Jehoram strengthened himself by killing all his brethren with the sword as recorded in 2 Chronicles 21:4.

questions.question: What foreign alliance influenced Jehoram's evil actions as king?
options: Marriage to the daughter of Ahab
questions.correctAnswer: Marriage to the daughter of Ahab
questions.explanation: Jehoram married the daughter of Ahab and walked in the ways of the kings of Israel, which was evil in the sight of the LORD (2 Chronicles 21:6).

questions.question: What reason does the text give for the LORD not destroying the house of David despite Jehoram's evil?
options: Because of the covenant with David
Because of the prayers of the people
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the covenant with David
questions.explanation: The LORD preserved the house of David due to the covenant He made with David to give a light to his descendants forever (2 Chronicles 21:7).

questions.question: Which two regions revolted from Judah during Jehoram's reign?
questions.correctAnswer: Edom and Libnah
questions.explanation: Edom and Libnah revolted from Judah because Jehoram forsook the LORD God of his fathers (2 Chronicles 21:8,10).

questions.question: What was Jehoram's age when he began to reign, and how long did he reign?
options: Thirty-two years old and reigned eight years
Twenty-five years old and reigned ten years
Thirty-five years old and reigned five years
Forty years old and reigned twelve years
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty-two years old and reigned eight years
questions.explanation: Jehoram was thirty-two years old when he began to reign, and he reigned eight years in Jerusalem (2 Chronicles 21:5).

questions.question: What sin did Jehoram commit that caused Libnah to revolt, according to verse 10?
options: He forsook the LORD God of his fathers
He built idols in the temple
questions.correctAnswer: He forsook the LORD God of his fathers
questions.explanation: Libnah's revolt was attributed to Jehoram forsaking the LORD God of his fathers (2 Chronicles 21:10).

questions.question: The writing from Elijah the prophet condemned Jehoram for several reasons. Which of the following was NOT mentioned in the letter?
options: Walking in the way of Israel's kings
Building the temple of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Building the temple of the LORD
questions.explanation: Elijah's letter rebuked Jehoram for walking in evil ways, killing brethren, and leading Judah into idolatry, but did not mention building the temple (2 Chronicles 21:12-13).

questions.question: What specific punishment did Elijah prophesy against Jehoram?
options: A great plague on his people and sickness of his bowels
Defeat by the Edomites and exile
Loss of all his cities and riches
Death in battle against the Philistines
questions.correctAnswer: A great plague on his people and sickness of his bowels
questions.explanation: Elijah prophesied a great plague on Jehoram's people and a grievous sickness of his bowels until they fell out (2 Chronicles 21:14-15).

questions.question: Which foreign powers did the LORD stir up against Jehoram as part of his punishment?
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines and Arabians
questions.explanation: The LORD stirred up the spirit of the Philistines and Arabians against Jehoram, who came and raided Judah (2 Chronicles 21:16).

questions.question: What happened to Jehoram's sons and wives during the invasion by the Philistines and Arabians?
questions.correctAnswer: They were carried away captive
questions.explanation: The invaders broke into Judah and carried away all substance in the king's house, including his sons and wives, leaving only the youngest son alive (2 Chronicles 21:17).

questions.question: How did Jehoram die according to 2 Chronicles 21?
options: From a disease of the bowels that was incurable
questions.correctAnswer: From a disease of the bowels that was incurable
questions.explanation: Jehoram was smitten in his bowels with an incurable disease, and his bowels fell out due to the sickness (2 Chronicles 21:18-19).

questions.question: How was Jehoram's burial different from that of his fathers?
options: He was buried in the city of David but not in the sepulchres of the kings
He was buried with great honor in the temple
He was cremated instead of buried
questions.correctAnswer: He was buried in the city of David but not in the sepulchres of the kings
questions.explanation: Jehoram was buried in the city of David but not in the kingly tombs, indicating a dishonorable burial compared to his ancestors (2 Chronicles 21:20).

questions.question: True or False: Jehoram's reign was marked by faithfulness to the covenant of David.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Jehoram did not walk in the ways of his father Jehoshaphat or Asa but followed the sinful ways of Israel's kings, leading to judgment (2 Chronicles 21:12-13).

questions.question: What literary device is primarily used in Elijah's letter to Jehoram, where the prophet contrasts Jehoram's behavior with that of Jehoshaphat and Asa?
questions.correctAnswer: Parallelism
questions.explanation: The letter uses parallelism by contrasting Jehoram's wicked ways with the righteous paths of Jehoshaphat and Asa, highlighting moral failure (2 Chronicles 21:12-13).

theological.title: 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from 2 Chronicles Chapter 21 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: What reason does 2 Chronicles 21 give for the LORD not destroying the house of David despite Jehoram's evil deeds?
options: Because of the covenant made with David
Because the people prayed for mercy
Because Jehoram was a good king at heart
questions.correctAnswer: Because of the covenant made with David
questions.explanation: 2 Chronicles 21:7 states that the LORD would not destroy the house of David because of the covenant He made with David, promising a perpetual light to him and his sons. This reflects God's faithfulness to His promises, consistent with Psalm 89:34-36 and 2 Samuel 7:12-16.

questions.question: According to 2 Chronicles 21, what was one of the consequences of Jehoram walking in the ways of the kings of Israel?
options: Edom and Libnah revolted from Judah
Jehoram was blessed with many sons
The temple of the LORD was rebuilt
questions.correctAnswer: Edom and Libnah revolted from Judah
questions.explanation: Verses 8 and 10 indicate that Edom and Libnah revolted because Jehoram forsook the LORD God of his fathers. This demonstrates the biblical principle that unfaithfulness to God leads to national instability (Deuteronomy 28:15-20; Judges 2:11-15).

questions.question: What specific sin of Jehoram is highlighted in 2 Chronicles 21 that provoked God's judgment?
options: He made Judah and Jerusalem commit whoredom like the house of Ahab
He refused to build the temple
He worshiped only the LORD faithfully
He gave gifts to his brothers
questions.correctAnswer: He made Judah and Jerusalem commit whoredom like the house of Ahab
questions.explanation: Verse 13 clearly states Jehoram caused Judah and Jerusalem to commit whoredom like the house of Ahab, symbolizing idolatry and spiritual unfaithfulness, which is a grievous sin against God (Exodus 20:3-5; Hosea 4:12-13).

questions.question: How did Jehoram treat his brothers according to 2 Chronicles 21?
options: He killed them with the sword
He made them rulers over cities
questions.correctAnswer: He killed them with the sword
questions.explanation: Verse 4 explains that Jehoram slew all his brethren and some princes of Israel. This fratricide represents a grave moral failure, violating God's commandment against murder (Exodus 20:13) and disrupting the covenantal blessings.

questions.question: What was the nature of the disease that God inflicted on Jehoram as judgment?
options: A sickness of the bowels with his bowels falling out
questions.correctAnswer: A sickness of the bowels with his bowels falling out
questions.explanation: Verses 15, 18, and 19 describe an incurable disease of the bowels causing his bowels to fall out. This severe, progressive judgment symbolizes the internal corruption of sin (Romans 6:23; 2 Corinthians 12:7-10).

questions.question: What role did the prophet Elijah play in Jehoram’s story as recorded in 2 Chronicles 21?
options: He sent a letter pronouncing God's judgment
He remained silent during Jehoram's reign
questions.correctAnswer: He sent a letter pronouncing God's judgment
questions.explanation: Verse 12 shows Elijah sent Jehoram a written prophecy condemning his disobedience and foretelling judgment, illustrating the prophetic office as God’s messenger (Amos 3:7; Hebrews 1:1).

questions.question: Which of the following best describes Jehoram's reign length and age when he began to reign?
options: Thirty-two years old; reigned eight years
Twenty-five years old; reigned fifteen years
Forty years old; reigned twenty years
Thirty years old; reigned ten years
questions.correctAnswer: Thirty-two years old; reigned eight years
questions.explanation: Verse 5 and 20 affirm Jehoram began to reign at age 32 and ruled for eight years, indicating the brevity and tragic nature of his reign (Psalm 90:10).

questions.question: What is the significance of Jehoram being buried in the city of David but not in the sepulchres of the kings?
options: He departed without being desired due to his evil reign
He was honored as a great king
He died in battle and was buried with soldiers
questions.correctAnswer: He departed without being desired due to his evil reign
questions.explanation: Verse 20 explains that Jehoram was not buried among the kings because of his wickedness and unpopularity, showing God’s judgment even in burial honors (1 Kings 14:10-11).

questions.question: What does 2 Chronicles 21 teach about God’s justice and mercy through Jehoram’s story?
options: God punishes sin but preserves His covenant promises
God ignores sin if the king is from David's line
God rewards all kings regardless of their deeds
questions.correctAnswer: God punishes sin but preserves His covenant promises
questions.explanation: Jehoram’s punishment for sin (verses 14-19) alongside God’s preservation of David’s line (verse 7) illustrates God’s justice in judgment and mercy in covenant faithfulness (Exodus 34:6-7; Romans 3:25-26).

questions.question: What was one political consequence of Jehoram's forsaking the LORD God of his fathers?
options: The Philistines became allies of Judah
questions.correctAnswer: Libnah revolted against Judah
questions.explanation: Verse 10 states that Libnah revolted because Jehoram forsook the LORD, confirming that disobedience to God leads to loss of political control (Deuteronomy 28:45-48).

questions.question: How does 2 Chronicles 21 describe Jehoram’s relationship with Ahab’s family?
options: Jehoahaz was married to Ahab's daughter
Jehoram married Ahab's daughter and imitated his evil ways
Jehoram was an enemy of Ahab's family
Jehoram expelled Ahab's descendants from Israel
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram married Ahab's daughter and imitated his evil ways
questions.explanation: Verse 6 states Jehoram had Ahab's daughter as wife and followed the evil ways of Ahab’s house, showing how intermarriage influenced idolatry and sin (1 Kings 16:30-33; 2 Kings 8:18).

questions.question: What did God say through Elijah’s letter about Jehoram’s failure compared to his father Jehoshaphat and Asa?
options: Jehoram did not walk in the ways of Jehoshaphat or Asa
Jehoram was more righteous than Jehoshaphat
Jehoram rebuilt the altar of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: Jehoram did not walk in the ways of Jehoshaphat or Asa
questions.explanation: Verse 12 shows Elijah’s rebuke that Jehoram departed from the righteous paths of his father Jehoshaphat and Asa, highlighting the spiritual decline from godly leadership (2 Chronicles 17:3-4; 2 Chronicles 14:2-3).

questions.question: Which nations did the LORD stir up against Jehoram according to 2 Chronicles 21?
options: Philistines and Arabians near the Ethiopians
questions.correctAnswer: Philistines and Arabians near the Ethiopians
questions.explanation: Verse 16 reveals God stirred the spirit of the Philistines and Arabians, illustrating divine use of foreign nations to execute judgment (Isaiah 10:5-6; Jeremiah 25:9).

questions.question: What was the fate of Jehoram’s family during the invasion described in 2 Chronicles 21?
options: His sons and wives were carried away except the youngest son Jehoahaz
All his family was killed in battle
His family was protected by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: His sons and wives were carried away except the youngest son Jehoahaz
questions.explanation: Verse 17 notes that the invaders took away all his sons and wives except Jehoahaz, showing the catastrophic impact of judgment on the royal household (Jeremiah 52:31-34).

questions.question: What theological theme is underscored by Jehoram’s death and the manner of his burial?
options: The dishonor due to persistent sin and rejection by people
The continuation of the Davidic covenant without interruption
questions.correctAnswer: The dishonor due to persistent sin and rejection by people
questions.explanation: Jehoram’s dishonorable burial (verse 20) reflects the biblical principle that persistent sin leads to shame and loss of honor (Proverbs 10:27; Ezekiel 21:25-27).
